query: What are the long-term effects of using municipal waste compost on soil fertility over a 20-year period?
relevant_summary: Two controlled, replicated trials in Spain and the United Kingdom measured the effect of adding municipal wastes or their composts to the soil [890]. One trial found that adding municipal compost to semi-arid soils greatly reduced soil loss and water runoff [890]. The other found mixed results of adding composts and wastes [890]. The soil types covered were coarse loamy and sandy loam [890]. Two other controlled, replicated trials from Spain and the United Kingdom measured the effect of adding organic processing wastes or their composts to soil [891]. One trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss, but increased nutrient loss [891]. The other trial found improved nutrient retention and increased barley Hordeum vulgare yield when molasses were added [891]. The soil types covered were sandy-clay, sandy loam, and silty-clay [891].

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"long-term effects of using municipal waste compost on soil fertility over a 20-year period"}
